item.title: u.s. shows growing alarm over japan nuclear crisis
item.description: the united states showed increasing alarm about japan's nuclear crisis on wednesday and urged its citizens to stay clear of an earthquake-crippled power plant, going further in its warnings than japan itself.

item.title: rangers' boogaard died of alcohol, oxycodone mix
item.description: the death of new york rangers enforcer derek boogaard was an accident, due to a toxic mix of alcohol and the powerful painkiller oxycodone.

item.title: strong ad market drives comcast and cbs results
item.description: comcast corp and cbs corp showed the tv business is even stronger than billed, reporting earnings that surpassed most forecasts and setting the stage for healthy price increases in the next round of ad sales.

item.title: for a galleon ex-manager, questions of motivation
item.description: raj rajaratnam's lawyer implied that adam smith, a government witness, had divulged that he had participated in an insider trading scheme only to try lessen his own sentence.

item.title: gbagbo is said to be close to defeat in ivory coast
item.description: laurent gbagbo deployed a band of loyalists to defend his residence, the state television station and the presidential palace in an effort to stay in power.

item.title: diamond foods buys pringles from pg for $1.5 billion
item.description: diamond foods inc will buy pringles from procter amp; gamble co for $1.5 billion in stock, snagging a global brand that will more than triple the size of its snack foods business.

item.title: sealed air to buy diversey holdings for $4.3 billion
item.description: the deal will make it easier for sealed air, a packaging company, to expand into commercial cleaning and sanitation.

item.title: as bank woes ease, the f.d.i.c.'s fund is building up
item.description: only four lenders were added to the government list of so-called problem banks in the first quarter, the smallest increase since the financial crisis began.

item.title: room for debate: will mubarak's trial unite or divide egypt?
item.description: is it a necessary step toward democratic reconciliation or does it raise risks of more anarchy and a violent military crackdown?

item.title: japan quake may alter where u.s. builds nuke plants
item.description: japan's nuclear crisis will influence where the united states builds future nuclear power plants, and the operation of a facility near new york city will be reviewed in the wake of the disaster, u.s. energy secretary steven chu said on sunday.

item.title: sports inflation: prices for masters 'badges' up 50 darsad

item.description: iran plans to protest to fifa over an official's decision to bar its women's national team from playing in an olympic qualifier because the players were wearing the traditional muslim head dress, the hajib.

item.description: the international energy agency cut its forecast for crude oil demand next year, citing the recent surge in petroleum prices and weakening growth prospects for industrialized countries.

item.description: djokovic won the italian open final in rome to stretch his unbeaten start this year to 37 matches.

item.description: mayor rahm emanuel of chicago took the stand for less than 10 minutes during the second federal corruption trial of former illinois gov. rod r. blagojevich.

item.description: justin verlander threw his second career no-hitter and the second in the major leagues this week, barely missing a perfect game.

item.description: mr. andrianov was a record-setting russian gymnast who had won 15 olympic medals, seven of them gold.

item.title: prince to play 21-night residency in los angeles

item.title: japan pm: must review oversight of nuclear power
item.description: prime minister naoto kan said on wednesday japan must rethink how nuclear power is regulated and explore other energy sources after a crisis at a tsunami-crippled plant, but sidestepped the question of how big a role atomic energy would play in the country's future.

item.title: china central bank chief: tightening to continue with yuan
